name: Skills Training Groups
summary: Skills Training Groups are structured, group-based interventions that teach practical coping, emotional regulation, and interpersonal skills to support mental health and daily functioning.
description: Skills Training Groups are therapeutic group interventions designed to teach participants specific skills for managing emotions, improving interpersonal effectiveness, enhancing coping strategies, and reducing maladaptive behaviors. These groups are often used as part of broader evidence-based therapies, such as Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT), but can also be stand-alone interventions. Skills training groups emphasize psychoeducation, modeling, role-playing, and practice exercises to help participants internalize and apply learned skills in daily life.

contraindications: High risk of harm to self or others in group settings
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe; group dynamics may occasionally lead to interpersonal conflict if not well-facilitated.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong for DBT-related groups; moderate for general psychoeducational skills groups.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Skills training groups, especially those integrated with DBT, have strong evidence for improving emotion regulation and reducing self-harming behaviors.

sections.text: Skills Training Groups work by providing participants with psychoeducation and structured practice in emotion regulation, interpersonal communication, mindfulness, and coping skills. The group format allows for peer support, role modeling, and feedback, which enhance learning and generalization of skills into daily life.

sections.preparation: Initial assessment to ensure appropriateness for group format and to set goals.
procedure: Facilitator provides psychoeducation on a specific skill topic.
Participants engage in role-play, modeling, or guided practice.
Group members receive and provide supportive feedback.
Homework is assigned to encourage skill practice outside of sessions.
sections.duration: Typically 8–24 weeks depending on the specific program.

sections.pre_session: Review of homework and group agreements.
sections.treatment_phase: Introduction of new skill, group discussion, and practice activities.
sections.post_session: Assignment of homework and reflection on skill use.

relative: High risk behaviors requiring more intensive intervention

ideal_candidates: Those who benefit from peer support
screening_required: Screening for safety and appropriateness of group participation

practitioner: Licensed therapists trained in group facilitation and specific skills program (e.g., DBT skills)

studies: DBT skills groups have robust evidence for reducing self-harm and improving functioning in borderline personality disorder.
Skills training groups show moderate efficacy for anxiety, depression, and substance use when integrated with other therapies.
sections.limitations: Effectiveness depends on facilitator skill and participant engagement; dropout rates can be higher compared to individual therapy.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under group therapy benefits
sections.cost_effectiveness: More cost-effective than individual therapy due to group format

lifestyle_recommendations: Application of skills to real-world contexts

sections.adolescents: Commonly used in adolescent DBT programs for emotion regulation and social skills.
sections.older_adults: Can be effective, though pacing and accessibility considerations may be needed.

items: Group cohesion enhances skill acquisition and motivation.
Homework completion strongly predicts treatment outcomes.
Facilitators must manage group dynamics to prevent conflicts or disengagement.

items.label: Linehan, M. (1993). Cognitive-Behavioral Treatment of Borderline Personality Disorder.
Panagioti, M., et al. (2017). Effectiveness of group skills training programs for borderline personality disorder: A meta-analysis.
